contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox settlement | name = Elkhorn | settlement_type = [[Ghost town]] | image_skyline = ElkhornMTfraternityhall.jpg | imagesize = 250px | image_caption = The Fraternity Hall | pushpin_map = Montana | pushpin_label_position = left | map_caption = Location of Elkhorn in Montana | coordinates_display = title, inline | coordinates_region = US-MT | coordinates_footnotes = <ref>{{cite gnis |id=783128 |name=Elkhorn}}</ref> | subdivision_type = [[List of countries|Country]] | subdivision_name = [[United States]] | subdivision_type1 = [[Political divisions of the United States|State]] | subdivision_name1 = [[Montana]] | subdivision_type2 = [[List of counties in Montana|County]] | subdivision_name2 = [[Jefferson County, Montana|Jefferson]] | established_title = Established | established_date = 1872 | named_for = Elkhorn Mountains | extinct_title = Abandoned | extinct_date = 1970s | elevation_ft = 6443 | coordinates_display = display=inline,title | latd = 46| latm = 16| lats = 29| latNS = N | longd = 111| longm = 56| longs = 45| longEW = W }} '''Elkhorn''' is a small [[ghost town]] in [[Jefferson County, Montana|Jefferson County]], [[Montana]], [[United States]], in the [[Elkhorn Mountains]] of the southwestern part of the state. ==History== Lodes of silver, described by geologists as [[Supergene (geology)|Supergene]] enrichments, were initially discovered in the Elkhorn mountains by Peter Wys, a Swiss immigrant.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ghosttowngallery.com/htme/elkhorn.htm |title=Elkhorn, MT |accessdate=2010-12-01}}</ref> Six years later, Anton Holter, a pioneer capitalist from [[Helena, Montana]], began developing the mine. Over $14 million in silver was carried from the mine. In 1890, the [[Sherman Silver Purchase Act]] passed, creating a high demand for Elkhorn's silver. During this peak period, Elkhorn boasted 2,500 inhabitants, a school, hotel, church, stores, saloons, and brothels. Unlike most mining towns, Elkhorn was populated mostly by married European immigrants.<ref name=MTGhost>{{cite web |url=http://ghosttown.montana.com/elkhorn.html |title=The Montana Ghost Town Preservation Society-Elkhorn |accessdate=2010-12-01}}</ref> In 1893 the Fraternity Hall was constructed for social gatherings, and still remains as one of the most well-preserved buildings in modern Elkhorn. In the years following, the silver boom and Elkhorn's prosperity began to lessen as the desire for silver decreased. A [[diphtheria]] epidemic also struck Elkhorn in the winter of 1888-1889, resulting in many deaths, particularly of children.<ref name=MTGhost/><ref>{{Cite web | title = Elkhorn, Montana Survives Today | work = Legends of America: Montana Legends | accessdate = 2012-12-29 | url = http://www.legendsofamerica.com/mt-elkhorn.html }}</ref> Soon after, railroad service to Elkhorn was halted and only a fraction of the original inhabitants remained. ==Geography== It can only be reached through its neighboring town, [[Boulder, Montana]] by taking the I-15 at Boulder exit, continuing {{convert|7|mi|km|0}} south on Montana 69, then {{convert|11|mi|km|0}} north on county graveled road. ==Demographics== While very few standing buildings remain of the original Elkhorn, a number of cabins have been reoccupied and refurbished. ==See also== * [[List of ghost towns in Montana]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.epodunk.com/cgi-bin/genInfo.php?locIndex=27715 Elkhorn, Montana profile] *[http://ghosttown.montana.com/elkhorn.html Montana Ghost Town Preservation Society] {{Jefferson County, Montana}} [[Category:Ghost towns in Montana]] [[Category:Geography of Jefferson County, Montana]] {{Montana-geo-stub}}
